sections.title: East India Association
sections.content_md:
*   **Founder**: **Dadabhai Naoroji** (**Grand Old Man of India**).
*   **Date & Location**: Founded in London, **1866**.
*   **Purpose**:
    *   To provide information on Indian subjects to British citizens and Members of Parliament.
    *   To voice the grievances of Indians and suggest remedial measures.
*   **Core Belief**: Based on Naoroji's opinion that the British were basically just and would resolve Indian problems if presented with the 'true state of affairs'.
*   **Branches**: Located in Mumbai, Kolkata, and Chennai.

sections.title: Achievements
sections.content_md:
*   Launched agitations against oppressive acts:
    *   **Licence Act**
    *   **Indian Arms Act**
    *   **Vernacular Press Act**
*   Protested lowering the age limit for the **Imperial Civil Service (I.C.S.)** examination from 21 to 19.
*   Supported workers on **British-owned plantations**.
*   **Limitation**: Failed to attain an **all-India character**.

sections.title: Lord Lytton organised a Grand Delhi Durbar in 1877
sections.content_md:
*   **Grand Delhi Durbar (1877)**: Organised by **Lord Lytton**.
*   **Purpose**: To proclaim **Queen Victoria** as the **Empress of India**.
*   **Criticism**: Lavish spending occurred while Indians were suffering from a severe **famine**.

sections.title: Birth of National Awakeing
sections.content_md:
*   **National Awakening** in India emerged in the second half of the 19th century.
*   **Causes**:
    *   Concepts of **nationalism** and **right of self-determination** from the **French Revolution**.
    *   **Socio-religious reform movements** (an offshoot of British-introduced modernisation).
    *   Indian reaction to **British colonial policies**.
*   **Outcome**:
    *   Generated **political awareness** and the formation of **political associations**.
    *   Culminated in the establishment of the **Indian National Congress** in **1885**.
    *   This marked the formal beginning of the **organised national movement in India**.

sections.title: The Peasants
sections.content_md:
*   Main victims of **British colonial policies**.
*   Cause: Government imposed heavy **land revenue** and other **taxes**.
*   Effect: **Exorbitant taxes** forced peasants into debt to **landlords** and **moneylenders**.

sections.title: Economic Exploitation
sections.content_md:
* **Economic Exploitation**: The most important factor arousing opposition to British rule.
* The central aim of British policies was to promote their own interests at the cost of the welfare of Indians.
* This resulted in economic discontent among different sections of society.

sections.title: His Approach of Religion
sections.content_md:
*   **Raja Rammohan Roy**: A great **humanist** who emphasized the **unity of all religions**.
*   **Influences**: Studied Sanskrit, Hindu philosophy, the Quran, Persian, Arabic, and Western thought. Learned Greek and Hebrew to study the Bible.
*   **Core Beliefs**: 
    *   Advocated for **Monotheism** (worship of one God), arguing it was the core of ancient Hindu texts.
    *   Opposed polytheism, **idol worship**, and meaningless **religious rituals**.
*   **Key Publications**: Wrote **Gift to Monotheists** (in Persian) to argue for the worship of a single God.
*   **Organizations Founded**:
    *   **1815**: Started the **Atmiya Sabha** to campaign against idol worship and rituals.
    *   **1828**: Founded the **Brahmo Sabha**, later renamed **Brahmo Samaj**.
        *   **Brahmo Samaj Principles**: Believed in Monotheism, condemned idol worship, and emphasized prayer, meditation, charity, morality, and unity between people of all religions.

sections.title: Upliftment of Women
sections.content_md:
*   **Jyotiba Phule**: Worked for the upliftment of women, whom he considered superior to men.
*   Promoted **education for women** as a means to empower them and make them aware of their rights.
*   **Key Actions & Dates**:
    *   **1848**: With his wife **Savitribai Phule**, started one of the first girls' schools in **Pune**.
    *   Subsequently opened more schools for girls and a school for untouchables.
    *   Pioneered the **widow remarriage movement** in **Maharashtra**.
*   **Overall Goal**: To achieve **socio-economic and gender equality** and liberate depressed classes through education.

sections.title: Ramakrishna Mission
sections.content_md:
### Ramakrishna Mission
- Founded by **Vivekananda** in **1897** to organize the disciples of **Ramakrishna**.
- Centre of activities: **Belur Math** (near Kolkata).
- Carried out **social service** through a network of branches, opening schools, hospitals, dispensaries, libraries, and orphanages.
- **Aims of the Mission**:
    - To manifest divinity inherent in man.
    - To strive for harmony among various faiths and cults.
    - To take up the service of mankind.

sections.title: Supremacy of Vedas
sections.content_md:
*   The **Vedas** were regarded as **divine revelation**.
*   **Swami Dayanand**'s motto was **"Go Back to the Vedas"**.
*   This created feelings of **self-confidence** and **self-respect** in people.

sections.title: Monotheism
sections.content_md: **Monotheism**: Preached against **idol worship** and taught faith in **one God**.

sections.title: The Artisans and Craftsmen
sections.content_md:
* **British economic policies**: Acted against the interests of Indian trade and industry.
* The **English East India Company** used its political power to destroy **Indian handicrafts and industry**.
* India was transformed into:
    * A **source of raw materials** for British industries.
    * A **market for its finished products**.
* **Effect**: This policy crippled **artisans** and **craftsmen**, depriving them of their livelihood.

sections.title: Opposition to Social Evils
sections.content_md:
**Arya Samaj**:

*   Opposed the **caste system**; membership was open to all.
*   Condemned **child marriage** and other social evils.

sections.title: The Working Class
sections.content_md:
*   **Working Class**: A new social class in India created by the growth of modern industries.
*   **Exploitation**: They were exploited by **factory owners**, who were generally Englishmen.
*   **Significance**:
    *   Though a small part of the population, they represented a new **social outlook**.
    *   Their outlook and interests were broad and pan-Indian, not just local to their city-based factories.
    *   This made their political thinking more significant than their numerical strength.

sections.title: The Educated Indians
sections.content_md:
*   **Educated Indians**: Faced limited employment, primarily in **government service** with high competition and poor promotion prospects.
*   **Initial Hope vs. Reality**: They had hoped British capitalism would develop India, but found British policies kept the country **economically backward**.
*   **Cause & Effect**: This realization led to the widespread belief that economic salvation required freedom from British rule.
*   **Impact**: Fostered the need for a unified **national platform**, providing a powerful stimulus to the spirit of **nationalism**.

sections.title: Shudhi Movement
sections.content_md:
**Shudhi Movement**
*   Initiated by **Swami Dayanand**.
*   **Purpose**: To bring back Hindus who had converted to other religions (re-conversion) and to check further conversions.
*   The **Arya Samaj** was instrumental in this movement, which played a role in the regeneration of Hinduism.

sections.title: Equality of Women
sections.content_md:
**Arya Samaj**:
*   Opposed **child marriage** and the **purdah system**.
*   Advocated for **equal status for women** and **female education**.
*   Encouraged **widow-remarriage**.
*   Established **orphanages**, and special **schools and colleges for girls**.

sections.title: Factors leading to the growth of Nationalism
sections.content_md:
### Factors Leading to the Growth of Nationalism

*   **Nationalism**: A feeling of oneness and common consciousness among people in a shared territory with the same historical, political, and cultural background.

#### Pre-British vs. British India
*   **Pre-British India**: Not a single nation, but many kingdoms. Loyalty was to a particular king, not the nation. Modern nationalism was lacking.
*   **Emergence under British Rule**: Modern nationalism emerged mainly as a reaction to British rule, caused by the **clash of interests** between the Indian people and the British.

#### Key Developments
*   Early resistance to British rule was localized and scattered.
*   This traditional opposition culminated in the **First War of Independence**.
*   **Impact of the War**: Though it failed, it inspired Indians to pursue a more determined struggle for freedom.
*   The nature of foreign rule itself fostered nationalistic sentiments and conditions for a National Movement.
*   National political consciousness and a strong feeling of nationalism emerged in the **second half of the 19th century**.

sections.title: Caste Structure
sections.content_md:
* The **caste structure** in India was considered an epitome of slavery.
* The book **Gulamgiri** described the hardships and distress of the lower castes.

sections.title: Indian Association (1876)
sections.content_md:
### Indian Association (1876)

- An **All-India Movement** founded in **1876** and headed by **Surendranath Banerjee**.
- **Members**: Lawyers, professionals, and the educated middle class.
- **Reach**: Had branches in Bengal and in towns outside Bengal.
- **Objectives**:
    - Create a strong body of **public opinion**.
    - Integrate Indian people on the basis of **common political interests**.
    - Promote friendly relations between **Hindus and Muslims**.
    - Encourage **mass participation** in public movements.

sections.title: Education
sections.content_md:
* **Swami Dayanand**: Encouraged the study of **Sanskrit** and the **Vedas** alongside **modern education**.
* **Arya Samaj**: Founded many schools and colleges called **Dayanand Anglo-Vedic (D.A.V.) schools and colleges**.
* **First D.A.V. College**: Established in **Lahore** in **1866**.
* **Legacy**: D.A.V. schools and colleges are now common in north India.

sections.title: Ideals of Swami Vivekananda
sections.content_md:
*   **Core Philosophy**:
    *   Proclaimed the **essential oneness of all religions** and condemned religious narrowness.
    *   Believed the Indian philosophical tradition of **Vedanta** was superior and destined to be the religion of mankind.
*   **Impact & Social Reforms**:
    *   Gave Indians **self-confidence** and pride in their past against perceived Western superiority.
    *   Condemned the **caste system**, rituals, and superstitions.
    *   Urged people to embrace **liberty, equality, and free thinking**.
*   **Humanism**:
    *   Believed that **service to mankind was service to God**.

sections.title: Social Reforms
sections.content_md:
### Socio-Religious Reform Movements (19th Century)

*   **Cause**: The impact of **Western education** led to a **rational, humanitarian, and scientific approach**, making educated Indians realize the need for reform.
*   **Goal**: Progress through a synthesis of the best of Eastern and Western ideas.

#### Key Areas of Reform

*   **Social Sphere**:
    *   Aimed to abolish the **caste system**, **child marriage**, **dowry system**, **purdah system**, **sati**, and **infanticide**.
    *   Fought against social and legal inequalities.
*   **Religious Sphere**:
    *   Combated **religious superstitions**.
    *   Attacked **idolatry**, **polytheism**, and **hereditary priesthood**.
*   **Core Principles**: Advocated for **individual liberty** and **social equality**.

#### Prominent Reformers and Organisations

*   **Raja Rammohan Roy**: **Brahmo Samaj**
*   **Jyotiba Phule**: **Satya Shodhak Samaj**
*   **Swami Dayanand Saraswati**: **Arya Samaj**
*   **Swami Vivekananda**: **Ramakrishna Mission**

sections.title: Repressive Colonial Policies
sections.content_md:
The nature of **British Colonial rule** fostered **national sentiment** in India.

*   **Cause**: The British implemented **repressive policies** to promote their own interests and make India subservient to Britain's needs.
*   **Effect**: These policies hindered India's economic, social, cultural, intellectual, and political development.
*   **Catalyst**: Policies enacted by **Lord Lytton**, **Viceroy of India** (1876-1880), were a significant catalyst for the growth of the nationalist movement.

sections.title: Lord Lytton introduced the Vernacular Press Act (1878) and Indian Arms Act (1878)
sections.content_md:
* **Vernacular Press Act (1878)**: Forbade vernacular papers from publishing material that might incite dissatisfaction against the British government.
    * Did not apply to English newspapers.
    * Repealed in **1882** by **Lord Ripon**.
* **Indian Arms Act (1878)**: Made it a criminal offence for Indians to carry arms without a licence.
    * Did not apply to the British.

sections.title: The maximum age limit for appearing in the Indian Civil Service examination was reduced from 21 to 19 years
sections.content_md:
- **Indian Civil Service examination**: Maximum age limit was reduced from 21 to 19 years.
- **Impact**: This made it more difficult for Indians to compete, as the exam was held in London.

sections.title: Socio-Religious Reform Movements
sections.content_md:
### Socio-Religious Reform Movements (19th Century)

*   Considered pioneers of **Indian nationalism**.
*   **Cause**: Impact of **Western education** led to a rational, humanitarian, and scientific approach, creating a desire for reform.
*   **Goal**: Progress by combining the best of Eastern and Western thought.

#### Social Sphere Reforms
*   Worked for the abolition of:
    *   **Caste system**
    *   **Child marriage**
    *   **Dowry system**
    *   **Purdah system**
    *   **Sati**
    *   **Infanticide**
*   Fought against social and legal inequalities.

#### Religious Sphere Reforms
*   Combated **religious superstitions**.
*   Attacked **idolatry**, **polytheism**, and **hereditary priesthood**.
*   Fought for **individual liberty** and **social equality**.

#### Key Reformers & Organisations
*   **Raja Rammohan Roy**: **Brahmo Samaj**
*   **Jyotiba Phule**: **Satya Shodhak Samaj**
*   **Swami Dayanand Saraswati**: **Arya Samaj**
*   **Swami Vivekananda**: **Ramakrishna Mission**

sections.title: Raja Rammohan Roy
sections.content_md:
* A leading **social and religious reformer** of the **19th century**.
* Aimed to eliminate **religious and social evils** prevalent in **Bengal**.
* Worked for the **religious, social, intellectual, and political regeneration** of India.
* According to Rabindranath Tagore, he was the **father of Indian Renaissance** and the **prophet of Indian Nationalism**.
* Credited with having "**inaugurated the modern age in India**."

sections.title: Lord Lytton removed import duties on cotton textiles
sections.content_md:
- **Lord Lytton** removed **import duties** on **cotton textiles**.
  - **Benefit:** **British cloth industry**.
  - **Cost:** **nascent Indian textile industry**.

sections.title: Political Rights
sections.content_md:
**Rammohan Roy**: Initiator of public agitation for political rights.

**Key Demands**:
*   Abolition of the **East India Company's trading rights**.
*   Abolition of heavy **export duties** on Indian goods.
*   **Separation of the executive and the judiciary**.
*   **Trial by jury**.
*   **Judicial equality** between Indians and Europeans.
*   **Indianisation of the superior services**.

sections.title: Jyotiba Phule
sections.content_md:
- **Jyotiba Phule**: An urban-educated member of a 'low caste'.
- His education and personal experiences led to his criticism of **Hindu religion** and customs.

sections.title: Sir C.P. Ilbert prepared a bill, popularly known as the Ilbert Bill in 1883
sections.content_md:
**Ilbert Bill (1883)**

*   **Author:** **Sir C.P. Ilbert**, Law member of the Viceroy's Council.
*   **Proposal:** To allow the trial of **British or European persons** by **Indian judges**, aiming for judicial equality.
*   **British Reaction (Cause):** Resented the bill and formed a **Defence Association** to defend their special privileges.
*   **Indian Reaction:** Educated Indians started a counter-agitation.
*   **Outcome:** The government **withdrew the Bill** under pressure.
*   **Consequences (Effect):**
    *   Highlighted the **racist attitude** of the British.
    *   Showed Indians that justice could not be expected when European interests were involved.
    *   Stimulated political agitation and quickened the pace of **Indian nationalism**.

sections.title: Swami Dayanand Saraswati
sections.content_md:
### **Swami Dayanand Saraswati**

*   **Original Name:** **Mool Shankar**
*   **Born:** **February 12, 1824**, in Tankara, Gujarat.
*   **Roles:** Philosopher, social reformer.
*   **Teacher:** **Swami Virajananda**, under whom he studied Sanskrit and the **Vedas**.
*   **Core Belief:** India's destiny depended on the revival of the **Vedic religion**.
*   **Key Contributions:**
    *   Founded the **Arya Samaj** in **1875** in **Bombay (Mumbai)**.
    *   Wrote the book **Satyarth Prakash**, which contains the philosophy and teachings of the Arya Samaj.

sections.title: Swami Vivekananda (1863-1902)
sections.content_md:
**Swami Vivekananda** (**1863-1902**)

*   Hindu monk, spiritual leader, preacher, and reformer.
*   Actively propagated **Vedanta philosophy** in India, the United States, and Britain.
*   **Birth**: Born **Narendranath** on **January 12, 1863**, in Calcutta (Kolkata).
    *   **Father**: Vishwanath Datta, an attorney and rationalist.
    *   **Mother**: Bhuvaneshwari Devi, a deeply religious woman.
*   **Spiritual Journey**: 
    *   Met his guru, **Ramakrishna Paramhansa** (a mystic and Kali devotee), in **1881**.
    *   Ramakrishna chose Narendranath as his spiritual successor.
    *   Was initiated into monkhood by Ramakrishna before his death in **1886**.

sections.title: Effects of Socio-religious Reform Movements on the Growth of Nationalism
sections.content_md:
### Contributions of Socio-Religious Reform Movements to Nationalism

- **Cultural Superiority**: **Swami Dayanand** and **Swami Vivekananda** proclaimed the superiority of Indian culture and civilisation.
- **Social Equality**:
    - Reformers condemned **untouchability** and the **caste system**.
    - Ideas of **brotherhood** and **equality** attracted the so-called lower castes.
- **Women's Participation**: Taught people not to ignore the importance of **women**, encouraging their participation in the national movement.
- **Political Consciousness**:
    - Protested against British domination of India.
    - **Swami Dayanand Saraswati** was the first to use the word '**Swaraj**' and raise the slogan '**India for the Indians**'.
- **New Society**: Created a consciousness of a new society devoid of privileges based on caste, creed, or religion.

sections.title: Role of the Press
sections.content_md:
### Role of the Press (Late 19th Century)

*   Numerous English (e.g., *Amrit Bazar Patrika*, *The Hindu*, *The Tribune*) and vernacular newspapers were established.
*   Played a significant role in developing **national sentiment** by:
    *   **Spreading Ideals:** Promoted messages of **patriotism** and liberal ideals like **liberty**, **freedom**, **equality**, **home rule**, and **independence**.
    *   **Criticising British Policies:** Carried out daily criticism of the unjust policies of the **British Government** and exposed the true nature of **British rule** in India.
    *   **Fostering Unity:** Enabled the exchange of views among different social groups and regions, helping to **organise political movements**.
    *   **Global Awareness:** Informed Indians about world events, which helped them shape their own policies and programmes.

sections.title: Pioneer of Indian Journalism
sections.content_md:
**Rammohan Roy**: A nationalist and **pioneer of Indian journalism**.
*   Published journals in Bengali, English, Hindi, and Persian with several goals:
    *   Spread scientific, literary, and political knowledge.
    *   Raise public opinion on current topics.
    *   Represent popular demands and grievances to the British government.
*   Launched two key weekly newspapers:
    *   **Samwad Kaumudi** (Bengali)
    *   **Mirat-ul-Akhbar** (Persian)

sections.title: FOUNDATION OF THE INDIAN NATIONAL CONGRESS
sections.content_md:
*   **Cause (2nd half of 19th Century)**: A growing consciousness that British control over India's resources and people prevented its sovereignty.
*   **Effect**: The formation of numerous **political associations**, led by English-educated professionals.
*   **Nature of Associations**:
    *   Though often regional, they held common goals for all Indians.
    *   They were secular, not working for any single religion, community, or class.
    *   Served as a foundation for an all-India political organization, the **Indian National Congress**.
*   **Key Forerunner Associations**:
    *   **Landholders' Society**: The first political association, started in Kolkata (**1838**).
    *   Other prominent ones included: **Bengal British India Society**, **British Indian Association**, **East India Association**, **the Poona Sarvajanik Sabha**, **London Indian Society**, and **Indian Association**.

sections.title: The World Parliament of Religions
sections.content_md:
*   **World Parliament of Religions**
    *   **Date:** 1893
    *   **Location:** Chicago, USA (Art Institute)
    *   Attended as a representative of Hinduism at age 30.
    *   **Key Speech Detail:** Began his address to 7,000 people with "Sisters and Brothers of America."
    *   **Effect:** Received a two-minute thunderous applause, establishing an instant connection with the audience.
*   **Post-Parliament Activities:**
    *   Toured the United States and London.
    *   **Purpose:** Promulgated **Vedanta philosophy**, gathering followers.
*   **Death:** Passed away on **July 4, 1902**, at age 39.

sections.title: Spread of the Movement
sections.content_md:
*   **Swami Dayanand**: Preached in **Punjab** and **Rajasthan**; died in **Ajmer** (**1883**).
*   **Successors & Spread**: His work was continued by **Mahatma Lekh Raj**, **Swami Shradhanand**, **Mahatma Hans Raj**, and **Lala Lajpat Rai**. The **Arya Samaj** spread rapidly, especially in **Uttar Pradesh** and **Punjab**.
*   **Key Ideological Difference (vs. Raja Rammohan Roy)**:
    *   **Dayanand**: Had faith in the infallibility of the **Vedas**.
    *   **Raja Rammohan Roy**: Believed more in **Western education**.
*   **Pioneering Ideas**: Was perhaps the first to preach "**Swadeshi**" and "**India for the Indians**'.

sections.title: Social Justice for Lower Castes
sections.content_md: *   **Satya Shodhak Samaj** (Society of Truth Seekers): Founded in **1873** to secure **social justice** for the weaker sections of society.

sections.title: Indian National Conference (1883)
sections.content_md:
*   **Indian National Conference**
    *   Convened by **Surendranath Banerjee** in **1883** at **Kolkata**.
    *   A provincial organisation that offered a model for the **Indian National Congress (INC)**, which was formed two years later.
    *   **Purpose**: To work for the welfare of Indians.
    *   **Merged** with the **Indian National Congress** in December **1886** as both bodies served the same purpose.

sections.title: FORMATION OF THE INDIAN NATIONAL CONGRESS
sections.content_md:
### Formation of the Indian National Congress

*   **Background**: Pre-existing political organisations were local. Leaders like **Surendranath Banerjee**, **Dadabhai Naoroji**, **Pherozeshah Mehta**, and **Badruddin Tyabji** sought an all-India political body.

*   **Role of A.O. Hume**:
    *   A retired British member of the **Indian Civil Service**.
    *   He wanted an organisation to draw government attention to administrative issues.
    *   In **1884**, Hume, with Indian leaders, founded the **Indian National Union**.
    *   He is regarded as the **Father or Founder of the Indian National Congress**.
    *   **Gopal Krishna Gokhale**'s view: If Hume had not been a British ex-official, the government would have suppressed the movement at its inception.

*   **First Session (1885)**:
    *   Initially convened in Pune but moved due to a plague outbreak.
    *   **Venue**: **Gokuldas Tejpal Sanskrit College, Mumbai**.
    *   **Date**: **December 28 to 31, 1885**.
    *   **President**: **Womesh Chandra Bonnerjee**.
    *   **Delegates**: Attended by **72 delegates**.

*   **Establishment & Naming**:
    *   On the suggestion of **Dadabhai Naoroji**, the name was changed from **Indian National Union** to the **Indian National Congress**.
    *   Foundation date: **December 28, 1885**.

*   **British Stance ('Safety-Valve' Theory)**:
    *   The Viceroy, **Lord Dufferin**, favoured the Congress's formation.
    *   He intended it to act as a **'safety-valve'** for popular discontent, thereby protecting British interests.

*   **Goal and Legacy**:
    *   The **Congress** represented the hopes of the Indian people and led the freedom movement.
    *   It achieved its goal of freedom in **1947**.

sections.title: Aims of the Indian National Congress
sections.content_md:
### Aims of the Indian National Congress

Declared by **W.C. Bonnerjee** in his presidential address at the first session:

*   **Promote friendly relations** between nationalist political workers from different parts of the country.
*   **Develop and consolidate feelings of national unity**, irrespective of caste, religion, or province.
*   **Formulate popular demands** and present them to the government.
*   **Train and organise public opinion** in the country.

**Additional Points:**
*   The Congress held sessions every year in December to plan programs to achieve these aims.
*   Aims were modified over time according to changing circumstances.

sections.title: Sessions of the Congress
sections.content_md:
### Early Sessions
*   **First Session:** Presided over by **W.C. Bonnerjee**, attended by 72 delegates including **Dadabhai Naoroji**, **K.T. Telang**, **Pherozeshah Mehta**, **Badruddin Tyabji**, and **Justice Ranade**.
*   **Second Session (1886, Kolkata):** Presided over by **Dadabhai Naoroji**. Some delegates were received by Viceroy **Lord Dufferin**.
*   **Growth:** The Congress met annually in December in different parts of the country, with delegates increasing to thousands.

### The Surat Split & Reunification
*   **Surat Session (1907):** The 23rd session, presided over by **Rashbehari Ghosh**.
*   **Cause:** A dispute between the **Early Nationalists** and **Assertive Nationalists** regarding agitation methods after the partition of Bengal.
*   **Effect:** A **split in the Congress**. The Assertive group was excluded for nearly a decade.
*   **Lucknow Session (1916):** The two wings of the Congress were reunited.

### Important Resolutions at Key Sessions
*   **1907 (23rd, Surat):** Split between the two wings of Congress.
*   **1911 (26th, Kolkata):** The National Anthem, **Jana Gana Mana**, was sung for the first time.
*   **1916 (31st, Lucknow):** Joint session with the **Muslim League** and signing of the **Lucknow Pact**.
*   **1924 (39th, Belgaum):** **Mahatma Gandhi** presided over this session.
*   **1929 (44th, Lahore):** Declaration of **Poorna Swaraj** (Complete Independence) and resolution to launch the **Civil Disobedience Movement**.
*   **1938 (51st, Haripura):** **Subhas Chandra Bose** was elected as President.
